output.rationale: This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (along with PM10) exposure and respiratory hospital admissions using distributed lag non-linear models, which is consistent with time-series methodology. The study reports associations with admission risk for specific respiratory diseases (asthma and COPD), indicating quantitative effect estimates are provided. While the study compares pre- and post-COVID-19 periods, it still meets the core inclusion criteria.

The study meets most inclusion criteria: original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, respiratory ED visits for asthma exacerbations, and appears to use a time-series design (quasi-Poisson regression with daily data). However, the abstract does not explicitly state whether a quantitative effect estimate (RR, OR, or equivalent) with confidence interval is reported. The abstract mentions statistical significance (P<10-4) and describes a non-linear relationship but does not provide the actual effect measure. Without access to the full text to confirm reporting of effect estimates with CIs, the decision remains uncertain.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) Asthma hospitalization is a respiratory hospitalization outcome, (4) Time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) Reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (0.31% increase per 1-μg/m3 PM2.5, 95% CI 0.24-0.37%), (6) Published in English. Although multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed with separate effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design; (2) PM2.5 was the primary pollutant (62% of days) and pollutant-specific analyses were conducted; (3) outcomes include both ED visits and hospitalizations for asthma, a respiratory condition; (4) case-crossover design is specified; (5) odds ratios with 95% CIs are reported; (6) published in English. Although the primary exposure measure is AQI rather than PM2.5 directly, the study explicitly analyzes PM2.5-specific effects and states PM2.5 was the dominant pollutant driving the association.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design; (2) exposure is PM2.5; (3) outcomes include respiratory hospitalizations (32 respiratory discharge diagnoses); (4) study design is case-crossover; (5) the abstract indicates associations were estimated for PM2.5 and respiratory outcomes, with groups showing positive associations, suggesting effect estimates are reported; (6) published in English. Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, the respiratory hospitalization component is relevant to the review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original time-series epidemiological study examining the association between PM2.5 (among other air pollutants) and hospital admissions for respiratory diseases. It reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (RR for PM2.5: 1.030, 95% CI: 1.012-1.049). The study uses a distributed lag nonlinear model for time-series analysis and appears to be published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using retrospective data, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly mentioned as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) Outcome includes both respiratory emergency department presentations and hospitalizations for bronchiolitis, (4) Uses time-stratified case-crossover design, (5) Reports odds ratios with quantitative effect estimates (>10% increased risk for PM2.5), and (6) Published in English. The study analyzes multiple pollutants including PM2.5, which is acceptable per inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed, (3) Outcome is respiratory hospitalization (acute upper respiratory infections), (4) Time-series design explicitly stated, (5) Reports relative risk with 95% CI (RR=1.0247, 95% CI: 1.0092,1.0405 for PM2.5), and (6) Published in English. Although it examines multiple pollutants, PM2.5 is included and analyzed with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcomes are respiratory hospitalizations and emergency department visits, (4) study design is case-crossover as explicitly stated, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., OR = 1.84, 95% CI = 1.13-3.00), and (6) published in English. Although the population is specific (childhood cancer survivors), this does not disqualify it from the review as it still examines the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization association.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants), assesses respiratory hospitalizations (bronchiolitis), and reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals (OR=1.04 [1.02-1.06] for PM2.5). The study is published in English and provides quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure includes fine particulate matter (PM2.5), (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations in children, (4) uses case-crossover study design, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., OR=1.004 [0.955-1.056] and stratified estimates), and (6) published in English. The study examines effect modification by particle constituents but still provides effect estimates for PM2.5 mass concentrations.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (time-series design, PM2.5 exposure, reports RR with effect estimates, appears to be original research), the outcome is hospitalization specifically for SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 infection rather than general respiratory hospitalizations. COVID-19 hospitalizations represent a specific infectious disease outcome rather than the broader category of respiratory hospitalizations that would typically include conditions like asthma, COPD exacerbations, pneumonia, etc. The research question focuses on air pollution's association with COVID-19 susceptibility/severity rather than respiratory disease hospitalizations in general.

This is an original epidemiological study using time-series design to examine PM2.5 exposure and asthma emergency department visits. It reports quantitative effect estimates (rate ratios with 95% credible intervals) for PM2.5 and other pollutants. Asthma ED visits are a respiratory outcome meeting the inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports both respiratory ED presentations and hospital admissions as outcomes, and provides quantitative effect estimates (incidence rate ratios) with 95% confidence intervals. The abstract is in English and contains all necessary information.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using time-series design; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures; (3) The outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory diseases; (4) It uses a time-series study design with generalized additive models and distributed lag nonlinear models; (5) Effect estimates are reported (e.g., 8.3% and 12.1% increases in risk for temperature extremes, and positive lag effects for PM2.5 are mentioned); (6) The article appears to be in English. While the abstract focuses on multiple pollutants and temperature, PM2.5 is clearly included in the analysis with quantitative results.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis with GAM, (2) exposure includes PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory disease hospitalizations, (4) study design is time-series, (5) the abstract indicates that PM exposures were associated with increased risks of hospitalizations, suggesting effect estimates were reported, and (6) the article appears to be in English. While PM10 is also examined, PM2.5 is explicitly included as an exposure of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) exposure is wildfire smoke PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (acute respiratory infections, pneumonia, COPD, asthma, and other respiratory diseases), (4) case-crossover design is explicitly stated, (5) reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals, and (6) published in English. Although the study examines both cardiovascular and respiratory outcomes, it clearly includes respiratory hospitalizations as a key outcome measure.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (URTI). Uses time-series design with generalized additive Poisson model. Reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CI (0.84% increase per 10 μg/m³, 95% CI 0.05-1.64%). Upper respiratory tract infections qualify as respiratory hospitalizations. Meets all inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 as one of multiple exposures analyzed with specific effect estimates reported, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (asthma and COPD), (4) time-series design explicitly stated, (5) reports risk ratios with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (RR: 0.981-1.148 for asthma; RR: 0.966-1.019 for COPD), and (6) published in English. Although the main findings were for NO2 rather than PM2.5, PM2.5 was analyzed and quantitative results were provided.

While this study examines PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates, it uses a retrospective cohort design with distributed lag models rather than the specified time-series or case-crossover design. The study analyzes daily county-level hospitalization rates as a cohort analysis, not individual-level time-series or case-crossover methodology.

Although this study examines PM2.5 exposure (from wildfire smoke) and includes respiratory ED visits as one outcome with reported effect estimates, the primary focus is on cardiovascular and cerebrovascular outcomes, not respiratory hospitalizations. The study uses an appropriate time-series design, but does not meet the inclusion criteria because the main outcomes are cardiovascular/cerebrovascular rather than respiratory conditions.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory ED visits (specifically pneumonia and COPD/asthma). It uses a time-series design with distributed lag models and quasi-Poisson regression on daily data. The study reports quantitative effect estimates (RR with 95% CI) for the association between PM2.5 and respiratory outcomes including pneumonia. Although the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes and other pollutants, it clearly meets all inclusion criteria for the respiratory hospitalization/ED visit component.

Although this study examines PM2.5 exposure and respiratory (pneumonia) hospitalizations with reported effect estimates, the study design is a prospective cohort rather than the required time-series or case-crossover design. The inclusion criteria specifically limit eligible studies to time-series or case-crossover designs only.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory emergency room visits using a time-series design (generalized additive model with lag structures). It reports multiple relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for overall PM2.5 and source-specific PM2.5. The outcome is respiratory ED visits, which satisfies the hospitalization/ED visit criterion.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) case-crossover design is specified, (5) quantitative effect estimates are reported (percentage change in odds with 95% CI per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5), and (6) the article is published in English. The study reports a 1.2% increase in odds of admission per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5 concentration.

Although this is an original time-series study with PM2.5 exposure that reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is hospitalization for rheumatoid arthritis-associated interstitial lung disease (RA-ILD), which is a specific autoimmune/rheumatologic condition with pulmonary involvement, not a general respiratory hospitalization. The inclusion criteria specify respiratory hospitalizations, which typically refer to conditions like asthma, COPD, pneumonia, or general respiratory diseases, not autoimmune diseases with lung manifestations.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory ED visits as outcomes (including asthma/wheeze, bronchitis, pneumonia, and upper respiratory infections), provides odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and is published in English in a peer-reviewed journal.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 and respiratory health; (2) Exposure is PM2.5 (plus POC and SOC); (3) Outcomes are respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for asthma and COPD; (4) Uses time-stratified case-crossover design; (5) Reports excess rates (ERs) with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., ER = 2.1%, 95% CI = 0.7%, 3.6%); (6) Published in English. All inclusion criteria are satisfied.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, time-series design using GAM), the outcome is outpatient visits rather than hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The title mentions 'hospitalization' but the abstract clearly describes the outcome as 'outpatient visits for upper respiratory tract infections,' which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory outcomes including both ED visits and hospitalizations. The study uses daily county-level counts linked with PM2.5 estimates analyzed with Poisson regression, which is consistent with a time-series design. The abstract reports multiple relative risk estimates with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes (respiratory disease RR: 1.25, 95% CI: 1.21, 1.30; CLRD RR: 1.18, 95% CI: 1.10, 1.27). All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the air pollutants examined, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalization (AECOPD hospitalizations are a specific type of respiratory hospitalization), (4) study design is time-series with Poisson regression and DLNM, (5) quantitative effect estimates are reported (RERI and RR with 95% CI), and (6) appears to be published in English. While the study examines multiple pollutants and temperature interactions, PM2.5 effects on respiratory hospitalizations are specifically analyzed and reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design to examine the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospital admissions in Kuwait. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (1.61% increase per 10 μg/m3, 95% CI = 0.87, 2.35%). The exposure is PM2.5, the outcome is respiratory hospitalizations, and the methodology clearly describes a time-series regression analysis with distributed lag models.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, (2) the exposure is source-specific PM2.5, (3) the outcomes are respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for influenza and pneumonia, (4) it reports quantitative effect estimates (excess rates with 95% CIs), and (5) appears to be published in English. The focus on respiratory infections (influenza and pneumonia) qualifies as respiratory hospitalization/ED visit outcomes.

This is an original time-series study using generalized additive models examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and emergency department visits for upper respiratory tract infection. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals. Although URTI is a specific type of respiratory condition, it meets the criteria for respiratory ED visits and the study design and methodology align with inclusion requirements.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a generalized additive model, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospitalization (pneumonia and asthma), (4) the study design is time-series based on the methodology described (ecological study analyzing daily hospitalizations against daily pollutant concentrations with lag structures), (5) quantitative effect estimates are reported with 95% confidence intervals (2.22% increase per 10-unit PM2.5 increase, 95%CI: 0.64%, 3.82%), and (6) the article is published in English. Although multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is one of them with specific effect estimates reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using time-series analysis; (2) Exposure is PM2.5 fine particulate matter; (3) Outcome is asthma emergency room admissions, which are respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits; (4) Study design is time-series; (5) Reports a quantitative effect estimate of 7.2% increase with 95% CI (1.7-13.1%); (6) Published in English. The study specifically examines asthma morbidity (a respiratory condition) and hospital/ED admissions.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study with case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly mentioned as one of the exposures assessed, (3) outcome is hospital admission for interstitial lung diseases which are respiratory conditions, (4) case-crossover design, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals. Although the abstract primarily reports results for SO2 and NO2, PM2.5 was measured and analyzed as stated in the methods, making it eligible for inclusion in a PM2.5 systematic review.

While this is a time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory hospitalizations with effect estimates, the abstract does not report the specific RR/OR for PM2.5 and respiratory outcomes. The results section only presents effect estimates for NO2, ozone, and noise - not for PM2.5, despite PM2.5 being listed as an exposure variable. Without the PM2.5-specific effect estimate for respiratory hospitalizations in the abstract, the study cannot be properly evaluated for inclusion.

This study meets the inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with generalized additive models and distributed lag models. PM2.5 is explicitly mentioned as one of the exposures analyzed. The outcome is hospitalizations for COPD, which is a respiratory condition. The study reports quantitative effect estimates (percent increases in daily admissions). The only minor uncertainty is whether confidence intervals are reported for the effect estimates, though the abstract mentions 'significant' findings suggesting statistical testing was performed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) examines PM2.5 exposure (along with PM2.5-10), (3) outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) case-crossover study design, (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (1.73% increase with 95% CI: 1.34%, 2.12% for PM2.5), and (6) published in English. Although it also examines PM2.5-10, PM2.5 is clearly one of the main exposures analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia, acute bronchitis, bronchiolitis, asthma), (4) ecological time-series design, (5) reports relative risk estimates with specific values (RR = 1.017, 1.022, 1.020 at different lags), and (6) published in English. The study uses appropriate statistical methods (generalized additive Poisson regression) and provides quantitative effect estimates for the association between PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

This study meets most inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospital admissions with quantitative RR estimates and CIs. However, the study design is described as a 'difference-in-differences approach' with distributed lag non-linear models, which is neither a traditional time-series nor case-crossover design. While it uses daily data and appears to have time-series characteristics, the difference-in-differences methodology represents a different analytical approach. The study should likely be included given it meets the spirit of the inclusion criteria, but the non-standard study design creates uncertainty.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly listed as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) The outcome is emergency department visits for respiratory diseases (COPD and upper respiratory diseases), (4) The study design is case-crossover as stated, (5) The abstract reports positive results/associations which implies quantitative effect estimates were calculated, and (6) The article appears to be in English. Although the abstract does not explicitly state the type of effect measure (RR, OR), case-crossover studies typically report ORs, and the mention of 'positive results' and 'associations' strongly suggests quantitative estimates were reported in the full text.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original time-series epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (acute lower respiratory infections including pneumonia, COPD exacerbations, and chronic bronchitis exacerbations). The study reports quantitative effect estimates as percent increases with 95% confidence intervals for various respiratory outcomes. The abstract is in English and clearly describes the methodology and results.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and hospital admissions for multiple disease categories including respiratory diseases. The study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (e.g., percent increase per 10-μg/m3 PM2.5 with 95% CI). Although the study examines multiple organ systems, respiratory hospitalizations are specifically included as one of the 7 major disease categories analyzed, making it eligible for the systematic review.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure (along with PM2.5-bound PAHs) and asthma emergency room visits. It uses a time-series design with generalized additive model of Poisson regression, analyzing daily counts of ERVs. The study reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for both PM2.5 and PM2.5-bound PAH exposures. Asthma emergency room visits qualify as respiratory emergency department visits, meeting the outcome criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using time-series design; (2) Exposure includes PM2.5; (3) Outcome is respiratory hospital admissions; (4) Time-series study design explicitly stated; (5) Reports percentage change with 95% CI (PM2.5: 0.755%; 95% CI: 0.422, 1.089%); (6) Published in English. The study analyzes both PM2.5 and PM10, which is acceptable as PM2.5 is one of the exposures analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 as exposure, (3) outcome is asthma-related emergency department visits (AEDv) which is a respiratory ED visit, (4) uses time-series design with Poisson regression, (5) reports relative risks with specific effect estimates (4.4% increase per IQR of PM2.5), and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants are analyzed, PM2.5 is specifically included and analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) outcome is asthma-related hospital admissions and ED visits (respiratory hospitalizations), (4) uses case-crossover design, (5) reports associations with 95% confidence intervals mentioned in results, and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants are studied, PM2.5 is explicitly included and analyzed.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using a generalized additive model (GAM), which is consistent with time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as an exposure; (3) Respiratory hospitalizations are included as one of the outcomes studied; (4) The study design is time-series based on the use of GAM with daily data during 2015-2016; (5) Quantitative effect estimates are reported with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., 1.03% increase in respiratory HAs per 10 μg/m3 PM2.5, 95% CI: 0.50%-1.56%); (6) The abstract is in English. Although the study examines multiple outcomes beyond respiratory hospitalizations, it clearly reports specific results for respiratory hospitalizations with PM2.5 exposure.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 (among other particle metrics) and hospital admissions including respiratory outcomes. While the abstract emphasizes cardiovascular results, it explicitly states that secondary pollutants including PM2.5 were important for respiratory outcomes. The study uses Poisson regression time-series analysis, examines emergency hospital admissions, and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals. All inclusion criteria are met.

This is an original time-series study using generalized additive models (GAMs) to analyze daily hospital admissions. It examines PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals for multiple disease categories including respiratory system diseases. NO2 showed significant effects on respiratory hospitalizations (1.36%, 95%CI: 0.74-1.98%). The study meets all inclusion criteria: original epidemiological study, includes PM2.5 exposure, includes respiratory hospitalization outcomes, uses time-series design, and reports effect estimates with CIs.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using time-series design with Poisson regression; examines PM2.5 exposure (alongside PM10); assesses respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits for asthma exacerbations; reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals; and appears to be published in English. Asthma exacerbations requiring hospitalization or ED visits are a specific type of respiratory hospitalization outcome that fits the review scope.

Although this is a time-series study examining respiratory ED visits and PM2.5 was controlled for in the model, the primary exposure of interest is thunderstorm-related climate parameters (precipitation and temperature), not PM2.5. The results explicitly state that PM2.5 was not significantly associated with asthma ED visits on thunderstorm days. PM2.5 was included only as a confounder/covariate, not as the exposure being investigated. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for a systematic review focused on PM2.5 as the primary exposure.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series design; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of multiple exposures; (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (ALRI including pneumonia and bronchitis); (4) time-series design with generalized additive model; (5) reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (e.g., RR=1.0064, 95% CI 1.0004-1.0124 for pneumonia); (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants are studied, PM2.5 is analyzed separately with specific effect estimates provided.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure (along with PM10), assesses respiratory hospitalizations (asthma and COPD), and reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals for the association between PM2.5 and hospital admissions.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using multicenter data; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures; (3) Respiratory hospital admissions are analyzed as an outcome; (4) Uses time-series design analyzing daily counts with Poisson regression; (5) Reports relative risk with 95% CI for PM2.5 and respiratory admissions (7.5% increase, 95% CI: 4.9-10.2%); (6) Published in English. While the study also examines ultrafine particles, PM2.5 is clearly one of the multiple exposures analyzed with separate effect estimates provided.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with multi-level Poisson regression; the exposure is PM2.5; the outcome is respiratory hospital admissions; quantitative effect estimates are reported (percentage increases in hospitalization rates per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5 for different racial/ethnic groups); and it appears to be published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations/admissions, (4) case-crossover design, (5) reports effect estimates with 95% CI (1.74% increase per 10-μg/m3 PM2.5 for respiratory admissions, 95% CI: 1.41-2.07%), and (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome with quantitative effect estimates (1.95% increase, 95% CI 1.63-2.27% per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5), and appears to be published in English. The study analyzed both cardiovascular and respiratory outcomes, but respiratory hospitalizations are explicitly reported with effect estimates.

While this is a time-series study that includes respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome and reports effect estimates, the primary exposure is particle oxidative potential (OP) rather than PM2.5 mass concentration. Although PM2.5 was measured and used to calculate OP metrics (OP per m3), the study's focus and effect estimates are for oxidative potential measures (OP_AA and OP_GSH), not PM2.5 concentration itself. This does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring PM2.5 as the exposure of interest.

This is an original epidemiological study examining fine particulate matter (PM2.5) exposure and emergency department visits for pediatric asthma. The study uses a time-series design (daily data 2002-2010 with Poisson generalized linear models), reports quantitative effect estimates (rate ratios with 95% confidence intervals), and focuses on respiratory outcomes. While the study examines source-specific PM2.5 contributions rather than total PM2.5, the exposure is still PM2.5, meeting inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using GAM methodology; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as an exposure; (3) Respiratory disease hospitalization is the outcome; (4) Time-series design (GAM for short-term effects); (5) Reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals (e.g., 1.95% (0.25, 3.67) for PM2.5); (6) Published in English. The study analyzes both PM2.5 and PM10, but PM2.5 is one of the exposures examined, which meets inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (asthma), (4) time-series design explicitly stated, (5) reports risk ratios with 95% CIs (e.g., RR 1.16, 95% CI 1.00 to 1.35 for asthma), and (6) published in English. While the study also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it clearly reports on respiratory hospitalizations including asthma, which is relevant to the review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures; (3) Outcome is chronic respiratory disease (CRD) hospitalizations; (4) Time-series study design clearly stated; (5) Quantitative effect estimates reported as excess risks with 95% CIs for PM2.5 (2.13%, 95% CI: 0.55%, 3.74% per 10 μg/m3 increase); (6) Published in English. Although multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically included and reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5/fine particulate matter, (3) outcome is respiratory healthcare visits/encounters which includes hospitalizations and ED visits, (4) case-crossover design is explicitly stated, (5) reports odds ratios with effect estimates for PM2.5 increases, and (6) published in English. While temperature is examined as an effect modifier, PM2.5 is the primary exposure of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a time-stratified case-crossover design; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly examined as one of the exposures; (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for childhood respiratory diseases; (4) the study design is case-crossover (time-stratified variant); (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals are reported (OR=1.017, 95%CI: 1.003-1.031 for PM2.5); and (6) the article appears to be published in English. No exclusion criteria apply.

This study meets the inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly mentioned as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcomes include emergency department and inpatient visits for asthma exacerbation (respiratory hospitalizations), (4) rate ratios with confidence intervals are reported, and (5) it appears to be published in English. Although the abstract only presents detailed effect estimates for grass pollen, it states that associations with PM2.5 were analyzed, suggesting that PM2.5 effect estimates are likely reported in the full text.

This study meets the key inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design (GAM with daily data), examines PM2.5 exposure among other pollutants, reports respiratory hospitalizations (for patients with comorbid respiratory diseases and diabetes), and provides quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs. While the population is restricted to patients with diabetes and comorbid respiratory disease rather than all respiratory hospitalizations, the outcome is still respiratory hospitalization and the study provides relevant PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization associations.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates (RR with CI), the outcome is acute upper respiratory tract infections (AURTIs), which are typically mild infections affecting the nose, throat, and upper airways. These do not constitute the lower respiratory tract conditions (pneumonia, COPD exacerbations, asthma) that are the focus of respiratory hospitalization studies. AURTIs usually represent less severe conditions that may not meet the criteria for 'respiratory hospitalizations' as traditionally defined in PM2.5 health impact studies.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using time-series design with generalized additive models; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as an exposure; (3) The outcome is emergency department visits for asthma, which is a respiratory condition; (4) Time-series study design is confirmed; (5) Quantitative effect estimates are reported as percent increases with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., 6.1% increase, 95% CI: 2.1-10.3%); (6) Published in English. While the study focuses on modification by wildfire smoke presence, it still examines the core association between PM2.5 and respiratory ED visits.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study analyzing data from 249 Korean communities, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations, (4) study design is case time series (a type of time-series design), (5) reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs (1.43% increase, 95% CI: 1.34%, 1.52% for respiratory hospitalizations per 10 μg/m³ increment in PM2.5), and (6) appears to be published in English. The study also examines cardiovascular outcomes but includes the required respiratory hospitalization outcome.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (COPD admissions), (4) uses case-crossover design, (5) reports effect estimate with 95% CI (1.6% increase, 95% CI: 0.6%, 2.7% per 10 μg/m3 increase in PM2.5), and (6) published in English

While this study examines PM2.5 as one of multiple exposures and uses a case-crossover design with effect estimates, the outcome is 'pediatric asthma visit treated with prednisone' rather than hospitalization or ED visit specifically. The results section states 'We observed no such associations with...fine particles (≤2.5μm)', indicating no significant PM2.5 effect was found. The primary exposure of interest is ultrafine particles, not PM2.5. Most importantly, the outcome definition is ambiguous and does not clearly specify hospitalization or ED visits as required by inclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using case-crossover design, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed, (3) the outcome is respiratory hospital admissions, (4) the study design is case-crossover (time-stratified), (5) the abstract indicates that associations and effect strengths were computed and reported for PM2.5, and (6) the publication appears to be in English. While multiple pollutants were analyzed, PM2.5 was specifically examined and showed significant effects in 2-pollutant models.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) exposure is PM2.5, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (COPD hospitalizations), (4) uses case-crossover design, (5) reports odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, and (6) appears to be published in English. COPD hospitalizations are a specific type of respiratory hospitalization.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) exposure includes PM2.5, (3) outcome includes respiratory hospitalizations (916,388 respiratory admissions analyzed), (4) study design is case-crossover as stated in the title and confirmed by use of conditional logistic regression, (5) quantitative effect estimates with 95% CIs are reported (0.26% increase, 95% CI = 0.22%, 0.31% for respiratory admissions per 10 μg/m³ increase in PM2.5), and (6) published in English.

This is an original epidemiological study using time-series methodology (Quasi-Poisson regression with distributed lag model) examining the association between PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (asthma, COPD). The study reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 and respiratory hospital admissions. Although multiple pollutants were examined, PM2.5 is specifically analyzed and reported. All inclusion criteria are met.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design, examines PM2.5 exposure, reports respiratory hospitalizations (pneumonia) as the outcome, and provides quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (12% and 4% increases in admissions).

The study focuses on coarse particles (PM2.5-10) as the primary exposure, not PM2.5. Although the abstract mentions PM2.5 in the context of adjustment for other pollutants, the main exposure of interest is coarse particles, which does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring PM2.5 as the exposure of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using GAM time-series analysis, (2) PM2.5 is explicitly studied as one of multiple exposures, (3) outcome is asthma hospitalizations (a respiratory hospitalization), (4) time-series design stated in title and methods, (5) reports RR with 95% CI for PM2.5 (RR=1.015, 95% CI: 1.003-1.028 per 10 μg/m3 increase), and (6) published in English. Asthma hospitalizations are a specific type of respiratory hospitalization relevant to the review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study, (2) includes PM2.5 exposure analysis, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization and ED visits for COPD exacerbation, (4) time-series design with Poisson regression, (5) reports RR with statistical significance for PM2.5, and (6) published in English. COPD exacerbation is a respiratory condition appropriate for this review.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design, examines PM2.5 exposure (along with ozone), focuses on respiratory emergency department visits as the outcome, and reports rate ratios with 95% credible intervals. Although it also examines ozone, PM2.5 is explicitly analyzed as one of the exposures of interest.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure from various sources, (2) exposure is PM2.5 (source-specific), (3) outcome includes respiratory emergency department visits, (4) case-crossover design is explicitly stated, (5) reports excess risk with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory outcomes including asthma EDVs, and (6) published in English. The study examines both cardiovascular and respiratory outcomes, but respiratory ED visits are clearly analyzed and reported.

This is an original time-series epidemiological study that examines PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and asthma hospitalizations. The study uses generalized additive models, reports quantitative effect estimates (mentioned positive and significant impacts), and calculates attributable risks. Asthma hospitalizations are a respiratory outcome meeting inclusion criteria. PM2.5 is explicitly mentioned as one of the pollutants analyzed. The abstract indicates effect estimates were calculated, though specific RR/OR values are not provided in the abstract itself.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It is an original epidemiological study using time-series regression with DLNM; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures analyzed; (3) The outcome is hospital admissions for respiratory diseases; (4) The study design is time-series; (5) It reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals (RR 1.089, 95% CI 1.001-1.183 for PM2.5); (6) The article is in English. Although multiple pollutants were examined, PM2.5 results are clearly reported with quantitative effect estimates.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a multi-city time-series design with generalized additive models; (2) PM2.5 is explicitly included as one of the exposures examined; (3) the outcome is hospital admissions for acute bronchitis, which is a respiratory hospitalization; (4) the study design is time-series; (5) quantitative effect estimates are reported with 95% confidence intervals (1.23% increase per 10 µg/m3 PM2.5, 95% CI 0.21-2.26%); and (6) the abstract is in English. Though multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is analyzed and reported separately.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study, (2) PM2.5 is included as one of multiple air pollutant exposures, (3) the outcome is asthma emergency department visits which qualifies as respiratory ED visits, (4) it uses a time-series study design as explicitly stated, (5) it reports rate ratios (RRs) which are quantitative effect estimates, and (6) it is published in English. While PM2.5 is analyzed alongside other pollutants (O3, CO, NO2, SO2), this is acceptable per the inclusion criteria.

The study includes PM2.5 (fine particulate matter) as an exposure variable and respiratory hospitalizations as the outcome, using a time-series design with generalized additive Poisson regression models. However, the abstract focuses primarily on temperature effects and only mentions that one model included the pollutant. Critically, the abstract does not report any effect estimates (RR, OR, or equivalent with CI) specifically for PM2.5 - only for temperature (18% increase for 4°C temperature rise). Without access to the full text to verify whether PM2.5 effect estimates are reported elsewhere in the paper, it is uncertain whether this meets the inclusion criterion of reporting quantitative PM2.5 effect estimates.

This is an original epidemiological study using time-series analysis to examine associations between PM2.5 (and ozone) exposure and cardiorespiratory outcomes including respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits. The study reports quantitative risk ratios with specific effect estimates for respiratory disease outcomes. While the study compares different visit types and includes both ozone and PM2.5 exposures, it meets the core inclusion criteria: original research, PM2.5 exposure, respiratory hospitalization/ED outcomes, time-series design, and reports effect estimates (RRs). The respiratory disease outcomes mentioned include asthma/wheeze which are relevant respiratory conditions.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using a case time series design; (2) exposure is PM2.5; (3) outcomes include respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits; (4) study design is time-series; (5) reports excess relative risk with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory hospitalizations and ED visits; (6) published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design with time-series analysis, examines PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants), reports respiratory hospitalizations (COPD exacerbations requiring hospital admission) as the outcome, and provides quantitative effect estimates (rate ratios with 95% CIs). The study is published in English and reports RR of 1.030 (1.006-1.055) for PM2.5 per 10 μg/m3 increase.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospital admissions (as well as cardiovascular). The study uses generalized linear models to assess associations and reports significant associations with effect estimates. It meets all inclusion criteria: original epidemiological research, PM2.5 exposure, includes respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, time-series design, and reports quantitative effect estimates with the statement that associations were 'significantly associated'.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 (among other pollutants) and respiratory emergency department visits for pediatric asthma. It uses a time-series design (generalized additive model with distributed lag model) and reports relative risks with 95% confidence intervals. The study meets all inclusion criteria: original research, PM2.5 exposure included, respiratory ED visits as outcome, time-series design, quantitative effect estimates provided, and appears to be published in English.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Original epidemiological study using time-series analysis; (2) PM2.5 is one of multiple exposures examined; (3) Outcome is respiratory hospitalization (asthma admissions); (4) Study design is time-series (with case-crossover mentioned in title); (5) Reports rate ratios with 95% CI for PM2.5 (RR=1.014, 95%CI: 1.000-1.028 per 10 µg/m3); (6) Published in English. Asthma hospitalizations are a valid respiratory hospitalization outcome.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) original epidemiological study using time-series regression analysis, (2) includes PM2.5 as one of the exposures examined, (3) outcome is respiratory hospitalization (acute lower respiratory infections), (4) time-series study design explicitly stated, (5) reports relative risk with 95% confidence intervals for PM2.5 (RR=1.089, 95%CI:1.075-1.103 per 10 µg/m3 increase), and (6) published in English. Although multiple pollutants were analyzed, PM2.5 is specifically included and reported.

This is an original epidemiological study examining PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations (including asthma and other respiratory outcomes) using time-series methods with Poisson regression. The study reports quantitative effect estimates (percentage increases) with 95% confidence intervals for respiratory hospitalizations. While it also examines cardiovascular outcomes, it meets all inclusion criteria for the respiratory hospitalization component.

This is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure (among other pollutants) and respiratory emergency department admissions in children. Although PM2.5 showed null findings, the study reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals for PM2.5. The study meets all inclusion criteria: it is an original epidemiological study using a time-series design with generalized linear Poisson regression models, examines PM2.5 as one of the exposures, assesses respiratory ER admissions as the outcome, and reports effect estimates with 95% CIs. Studies with null findings are important to include in systematic reviews to avoid publication bias.

While this is an interrupted time series study that examines PM2.5 exposure and includes respiratory hospitalizations as one outcome, it does not meet the inclusion criteria for study design. This is an interrupted time series examining long-term effects (8 years) of a single acute event, not a standard time-series or case-crossover design that examines the association between short-term PM2.5 fluctuations and respiratory outcomes. The study focuses on multiple outcomes (mental health, injury, cardiovascular) with respiratory being only one stratified category, and the conclusions emphasize uncertainty about whether effects were due to smoke exposure versus socioeconomic disruption. The abstract does not clearly indicate whether quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals for respiratory hospitalizations specifically are reported.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) it is an original epidemiological study using an 18-year time-series design; (2) PM2.5 (including speciated organic carbon fraction) is examined as an exposure; (3) the outcome is respiratory emergency department visits for infections including bronchitis, bronchiolitis, pneumonia, and URI; (4) it uses a time-series design with Poisson generalized linear models; (5) it reports quantitative effect estimates with 95% confidence intervals (e.g., 4% increase [95% CI: 2%, 6%] for URI); and (6) it is published in English. Although multiple pollutants are examined, PM2.5 is specifically included in the analysis.

While this is an original time-series study with effect estimates, it fails multiple inclusion criteria: (1) the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5; (2) the outcomes are pulmonary embolism and venous thrombosis, which are cardiovascular/thromboembolic conditions, not respiratory hospitalizations; (3) the study found no effect of particulate matter on the outcomes studied.
The outcome is suicide deaths, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The study fails to meet inclusion criteria 2 (wrong exposure) and 3 (wrong outcome).

This is a critical review of existing studies, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the exposure is PM10 (not PM2.5) and the outcome is mortality (not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit).

This is a review article (not an original epidemiological study) that examines the association between air pollution and coronary/cardiovascular disease (not respiratory hospitalization). It does not meet inclusion criteria 1 (original study) or 3 (respiratory outcome).

This is a meta-analysis/systematic review, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality rather than hospitalization or ED visits, and the exposure is PM10 rather than PM2.5.

While this is an original epidemiological study using a case-crossover design examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is out-of-hospital cardiac arrest of cardiac origin, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. The study does not meet inclusion criterion #3.

This is an animal experimental study conducted in mice, not an epidemiological study in humans. The study design is a controlled laboratory experiment testing a pharmaceutical intervention (Astragaloside IV), not a time-series or case-crossover study. The outcome is PM2.5-induced lung injury measured through biological markers, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. This clearly falls under the exclusion criterion for animal studies.

This is explicitly stated as a review ('this review is focused on these aspects') that discusses historical, physicochemical, and pathological aspects of particulate matter. It is not an original epidemiological study and does not report specific effect estimates from a time-series or case-crossover analysis. The abstract describes general mechanisms and outcomes rather than presenting original research on PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

The study examines PM10 exposure, not PM2.5. While it is an original time-series study examining respiratory hospitalizations with appropriate design, it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring PM2.5 as the exposure. The abstract explicitly states the exposure is PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm in diameter) with no mention of PM2.5 being analyzed.

While this study includes a multisite time-series analysis component examining PM2.5 constituents and reports effect estimates, the outcome is cardiovascular hospital admissions, not respiratory hospitalizations. The abstract specifically mentions 'cardiovascular hospital admissions' as the outcome. Additionally, the paper is described as combining a meta-analysis with a time-series analysis, which adds complexity to its categorization.

The study examines PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 μm) not PM2.5 (≤2.5 μm) as the exposure. While the study is an original epidemiological time-series analysis that reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals and includes respiratory hospitalizations as one outcome, it does not meet the fundamental inclusion criterion requiring PM2.5 exposure specifically.

While this is an original case-crossover study examining respiratory hospitalizations with quantitative effect estimates, the exposure is PM10 (particles ≤10 µm) rather than PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 µm). The abstract clearly specifies PM10 as the particulate matter exposure and does not mention PM2.5.

This study examines PM10 (particles ≤10 μm) exposure, not PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 μm). While it is an original time-series study examining respiratory hospitalizations with reported relative risks and confidence intervals, it does not meet the exposure criterion requiring PM2.5 as the pollutant of interest.

This appears to be a health impact assessment/policy evaluation study that uses relative risks obtained from a literature review rather than an original epidemiological study that directly analyzed the PM2.5-respiratory hospitalization relationship. The abstract states 'A literature review was carried out to determine the appropriate relative risk to be used in the estimations' and they 'calculated based on the selected relative risks for each city,' indicating they applied previously published effect estimates to estimate avoidable hospitalizations under a policy scenario, rather than conducting original time-series or case-crossover analysis.

The study examines PM10 (particles <10 µm) not PM2.5 (particles ≤2.5 µm) as the exposure. Additionally, the outcome is emergency ambulance dispatches rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. While respiratory diseases are mentioned, the specific outcome measure does not meet the inclusion criteria for respiratory hospitalization/ED visit.

Although this is an original epidemiological study with case-crossover design examining PM2.5 exposure and reporting effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is ischemic stroke hospitalization, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for outcome type.

This study examines PM10 exposure (not PM2.5) and cardiovascular events (not respiratory hospitalizations). Both the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria for this systematic review focused on PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

The study examines cardiovascular mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. While the exposure includes PM10 (and possibly other air pollutants), the outcome does not meet the inclusion criteria which specifically requires respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The abstract clearly states 'This systematic review was conducted' and mentions including '196 articles in quantitative analysis.' Additionally, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, respiratory, and cerebrovascular mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a review/book chapter that summarizes existing literature rather than an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality (all-cause and lung cancer), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (original epidemiological study, PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, reports effect estimates with CI), the outcome is myocardial infarction mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visit. The study focuses on cardiovascular outcomes rather than respiratory outcomes.

Although this is an original case-crossover study that includes PM2.5 as one of the exposures and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the outcome is stroke hospitalization (a cardiovascular outcome), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. This does not meet the inclusion criteria for a systematic review on respiratory hospitalizations.

The study examines coarse particulate matter (PM10) from mineral dust, not PM2.5 (fine particulate matter ≤2.5 µm). Additionally, the outcome is respiratory symptoms (cough) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study design is case-crossover which meets criteria, but the exposure and outcome do not match the inclusion requirements.

While this is an original epidemiological study using interrupted time-series analysis for respiratory hospital visits with effect estimates, the exposure is PM10, not PM2.5. The study evaluates the impact of a vegetation burning ban on air pollution and health outcomes, measuring PM10 concentrations specifically. PM2.5 is not mentioned in the abstract as an exposure variable.

The study examines coarse particulate matter (PM10-2.5) exposure and ischemic stroke hospitalizations, not PM2.5 exposure and respiratory hospitalizations. The outcome is cardiovascular (stroke), not respiratory, which does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The outcome is mortality (cause-specific daily mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. Although the study examines PM2.5 exposure using a time-series design and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, it does not meet the primary outcome criterion of the systematic review.

This is a systematic literature review/meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and explicitly exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Although the review mentions that some of the included studies examined PM2.5 and used time-series designs, this publication itself is a review article summarizing other studies.

Study fails to meet inclusion criteria on two key aspects: (1) exposure is PM10, not PM2.5 as required, and (2) outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. While it uses an appropriate time-series design and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, the exposure and outcome do not match the review's requirements.
This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and respiratory mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits). The exposure type and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria for this systematic review.

This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and uses years of life lost (YLL) from respiratory disease mortality (not hospitalizations or ED visits) as the outcome. The study does not meet the exposure criterion (PM2.5) or the outcome criterion (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The first exclusion criterion specifically excludes reviews and meta-analyses. Additionally, while PM2.5 is included as an exposure, the outcomes reported are mortality (respiratory mortality, cardiovascular mortality, etc.) and morbidity in general, not specifically respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits.

The study examines PM10 and NO2 as exposures, not PM2.5. While the study includes respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, uses appropriate study designs (Poisson regression/time-series and case-crossover), and reports quantitative effect estimates with confidence intervals, it does not meet the exposure criterion requiring PM2.5 or fine particulate matter ≤2.5 µm. PM10 (particulate matter ≤10 µm) is a different exposure category.
The study examines PM10 and O3 exposure, not PM2.5. Additionally, the outcome is mortality rather than hospitalization or ED visits. These are critical violations of the inclusion criteria.
This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) exposure and mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits) as the outcome. Both the exposure and outcome do not meet inclusion criteria.

While this is a time-series study with quantitative effect estimates, it does not measure PM2.5 exposure (only PM10, NO2, and SO2) and the outcome is respiratory disease mortality rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Both the exposure and outcome fail to meet inclusion criteria.

This study examines coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10, not PM2.5) as the primary exposure and mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits) as the outcome. Both the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria for this systematic review.
Study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and mortality (not hospitalization/ED visits) as the outcome. Fails to meet both exposure and outcome inclusion criteria.
This study examines PM10 exposure (not PM2.5) and respiratory mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits) as the outcome. Both the exposure type and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria.

While this is an original time-series study with quantitative effect estimates, it fails to meet two critical inclusion criteria: (1) The primary exposure is particle number concentration (PNC) and particle surface area concentration (PSC), not PM2.5. Although PM10 is mentioned for comparison, PM2.5 is not analyzed. (2) The outcome is mortality (natural, cardiovascular, and respiratory mortality), not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits.

This study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Additionally, the exposure is PM10, NO2, and O3, not PM2.5. The study fails to meet both the exposure criterion (PM2.5) and the outcome criterion (respiratory hospitalization/ED visit).

This study examines PM10 (not PM2.5) as the exposure and mortality (not hospitalization or ED visits) as the outcome. Both the exposure type and outcome fail to meet the inclusion criteria for this systematic review.
Study examines PM10 exposure (not PM2.5) and cardiovascular/coronary heart disease hospitalizations (not respiratory outcomes). Fails to meet inclusion criteria for both exposure type and outcome.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, and respiratory mortality) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study focuses on economic losses due to mortality, not hospital admissions.

The study examines coarse particulate matter (PM2.5-10, not PM2.5) as the primary exposure, and the outcome is respiratory mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Both the exposure and outcome do not meet the inclusion criteria.

Although this is an original epidemiological study with PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, and quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (all-cause, cardiovascular, respiratory/thoracic cancer) rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits, which is the required outcome for this review.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. Fails inclusion criteria 1 and 3.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (death counts and years of life lost), not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study does not assess hospital admissions or ED visits, which are the required outcomes for this systematic review.

While this study meets several inclusion criteria (PM2.5 exposure, case-crossover design, reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, published in English), the outcome is mortality rather than respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The systematic review specifically focuses on respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits, not mortality outcomes.

The study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. While the exposure is PM2.5 and the study designs (time-series and case-crossover) match the inclusion criteria, and effect estimates are reported, the outcome does not meet the inclusion requirements for this systematic review focused on respiratory hospitalizations.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. While the reviewed studies may have examined respiratory outcomes, this publication itself is a synthesis of other studies rather than primary research.

Although this is an original case-crossover study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The inclusion criteria specifically require respiratory hospitalization/ED visit as the outcome.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specify original studies only, and explicitly exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Additionally, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits.

Although this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality (deaths), not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The study examines respiratory deaths/mortality, which does not meet the inclusion criteria requiring respiratory hospitalization or ED visits as the outcome.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original epidemiological studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. While the underlying studies may have examined PM2.5 exposure and respiratory morbidity using appropriate study designs, this publication itself is a synthesis of other studies rather than original research.

The study examines mortality as the outcome, not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. While the study includes PM2.5 exposure, uses a time-series design (GAM), and reports effect estimates with confidence intervals, it does not meet the inclusion criteria for the outcome of interest.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits. The study reports respiratory mortality rather than respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits, which does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a multi-study research program report that includes epidemiologic studies, animal studies, and in vitro studies. While it mentions a time-series epidemiologic study (Ito study), the outcomes are described as 'morbidity and mortality' without specifying respiratory hospitalizations. The abstract focuses primarily on mortality outcomes rather than respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits specifically. Additionally, this appears to be a summary report of multiple integrated studies rather than a single original epidemiological study meeting the inclusion criteria.

While this study uses time-series data and includes PM2.5 as an exposure, the outcome is respiratory mortality (deaths), not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. The abstract specifically mentions 'deaths due to natural causes, cardiovascular disease, cerebrovascular disease and respiratory disease' as the health outcomes. Additionally, this appears to be primarily a methodological comparison paper (meta-analysis vs pooled analysis) rather than a primary epidemiological study reporting original associations.

The study examines ozone exposure as the primary exposure (not PM2.5), and the outcome is respiratory mortality (not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits). While the study mentions PM2.5 as a co-pollutant controlled for in the analysis, it is not the main exposure of interest. The outcome does not meet the inclusion criteria as it focuses on mortality rather than hospitalizations or emergency department visits.

While this is an original time-series study examining PM2.5 exposure with quantitative effect estimates, the outcome is respiratory mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or emergency department visits as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study), and the outcome is heart failure hospitalization/mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Fails inclusion criteria 1 and 3.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('have been described in this review') rather than an original epidemiological study. It discusses general health effects of PM2.5 including mechanisms and pathways, but does not report original data or specific effect estimates for respiratory hospitalizations.

This is explicitly described as a review ('In this review, we synthesize the scientific evidence') rather than an original epidemiological study. It synthesizes findings from multiple studies rather than reporting original data. Reviews are explicitly listed in the exclusion criteria.

This is a scoping review, not an original epidemiological study. It reviews 364 articles on climate change and neurologic health. Additionally, the outcomes are neurologic conditions (stroke, dementia, Parkinson disease, MS), not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. This fails multiple inclusion criteria.
This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria explicitly require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses.

This is explicitly stated to be a review article examining PM2.5-induced cell death mechanisms across different diseases. It does not report original epidemiological data, does not measure respiratory hospitalizations as an outcome, and does not report quantitative effect estimates like RR or OR. Fails multiple inclusion criteria.

This is a meta-analysis (not an original epidemiological study) examining the association between PM2.5 and myocardial infarction (MI), which is a cardiovascular outcome, not a respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. Fails inclusion criteria 1 (not original research) and 3 (wrong outcome).

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. While it does examine PM2.5 exposure and includes hospital utilization outcomes, it is synthesizing results from 59 other studies rather than presenting original research.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The inclusion criteria specifically require original studies and exclude reviews and meta-analyses. Although it examines PM2.5 constituents and includes respiratory morbidity outcomes, it synthesizes data from other studies rather than presenting original research.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('The current review investigate epidemiological and experimental findings from 2016 to 2021'), not an original epidemiological study. Reviews are excluded per the inclusion criteria.

This is explicitly identified as a review article ('this review article was prepared', 'In this review, we focus on') focusing on PM2.5 and chronic kidney disease, not respiratory hospitalizations. It fails multiple inclusion criteria: (1) it is a review, not an original study, (2) the outcome is kidney disease, not respiratory hospitalization/ED visits.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. It synthesizes findings from multiple studies rather than presenting original data. Additionally, the outcomes reported are respiratory and cardiovascular mortality, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits.

This is a systematic review and meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. The first inclusion criterion requires original studies only, and the first exclusion criterion explicitly excludes reviews and meta-analyses.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('In this review, we discussed the latest epidemiological advances'), not an original epidemiological study. Reviews are explicitly listed in the exclusion criteria.

This study examines mortality outcomes (deaths), not respiratory hospitalizations or emergency department visits. Additionally, the study design is a cohort study examining long-term exposure, not a time-series or case-crossover design as required by the inclusion criteria.

This appears to be a narrative review, commentary, or editorial discussing the general health effects of wildfire smoke and PM2.5. It does not describe an original epidemiological study with specific methods, data collection, or quantitative effect estimates. The language is descriptive and advocacy-oriented rather than reporting empirical research findings.

This is a review article (explicitly states 'In this review, we summarize...') focusing on toxicological mechanisms of PM2.5 on vascular endothelial cells, not an original epidemiological study. The outcome is cardiovascular/vascular effects, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Does not meet multiple inclusion criteria.

This is a rapid review/systematic review that synthesizes evidence from other studies (found 450 manuscripts, 15 met inclusion criteria). It is not an original epidemiological study. Reviews and meta-analyses are explicitly excluded per the exclusion criteria.

This is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is respiratory disease mortality, not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit as specified in the inclusion criteria.

This is explicitly identified as a review article in the title ('A review of implications for human health'), which violates inclusion criterion 1 and matches exclusion criteria. Additionally, the abstract does not describe an original epidemiological study, does not report any quantitative effect estimates (RR, OR, or CI), and does not specify respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits as outcomes. The focus is on general health impacts of ammonia and PM2.5 rather than presenting original research on PM2.5 and respiratory hospitalizations.

This is a review article (as stated in the abstract: 'This review summarizes and discusses studies'), not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is neurological (Alzheimer's disease and dementia), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visits. Fails inclusion criteria 1 and 3.

This study fails to meet multiple inclusion criteria: (1) It is a meta-analysis, not an original epidemiological study, and (2) the outcome is myocardial infarction (cardiovascular hospitalization), not respiratory hospitalization or ED visit. The study examines cardiovascular outcomes rather than respiratory outcomes.

This is a systematic review (not an original epidemiological study) examining ocular surface diseases (conjunctivitis, dry eye, blepharitis) rather than respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. Fails inclusion criteria #1 (not original research) and #3 (wrong outcome).

This is a review article (stated explicitly as 'In this review') focusing on cardiovascular effects and vascular smooth muscle cells, not an original epidemiological study on respiratory hospitalizations. It does not meet the inclusion criteria for study type or outcome.

This article focuses on cancer outcomes rather than respiratory hospitalizations/ED visits. The abstract describes a narrative/review article exploring PM2.5's relationship with cancer risks and mortality, and proposes mitigation strategies. It does not appear to be an original epidemiological study with time-series or case-crossover design reporting respiratory hospitalization outcomes.

This is explicitly stated as a review article (in both title and abstract), not an original epidemiological study. Additionally, the outcome is cardiac developmental toxicity/congenital heart defects, not respiratory hospitalizations or ED visits. The study also involves animal models and focuses on molecular mechanisms rather than quantitative epidemiological associations.

This is explicitly described as a review article ('The aim of this review is to provide a brief overview') focusing on in vitro and in vivo experimental studies, not an original epidemiological study. It does not report quantitative effect estimates from human epidemiological research with time-series or case-crossover design.

This is explicitly stated as a review article ('This review aims to summarize and discuss...'), not an original epidemiological study. It does not meet inclusion criterion 1.
